title: My Weird Winter with Bourbon Vanilla Tallow Balm (And Why It Worked)
body:
Okay so. My hands were a disaster. Like, cracking and bleeding disaster. It was December, maybe the 14th? I remember because I was trying to wrap presents and the paper kept catching on my knuckles. I’d been using this lotion from the big blue bottle, you know the one everyone has. The super thick one that smells like a hospital. It just sat on top of my skin. Like a greasy film. I’d put it on and ten minutes later my hands felt tight again, like I’d washed them with sandpaper. I was so mad about it. Standing there in my kitchen at 11 PM, looking at this stupid bottle I’d bought at the Target on Route 9, not the one downtown. What a waste of $8.99.

Anyway. I was scrolling, probably avoiding going to bed, and I saw someone talking about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your skin. I thought it was a joke at first. Like, what? But the person said it was for eczema and rough skin. And my skin was definitely rough. So I got curious. Skeptical, but curious. I found this little shop on Etsy, Malti, that made a whipped tallow balm. They had a Bourbon Vanilla scent. That sounded less weird than plain beef fat, I guess. I figured, worst case, I’m out thirty bucks and I have a very confusing jar of something. So I ordered it.

It showed up a week later. A little glass jar.

## How Beef Fat Became My Go-To

Opening it was an experience. It doesn’t smell like beef. At all. Which was my first worry. It smells like… vanilla. But not like cake. Or candles. It’s a deeper smell. Warm. Like if you walked into a kitchen where someone was baking something good with real vanilla beans, but hours ago, and the scent is just lingering in the air. Comforting. Not sweet. Just… good. The texture is weird. In a good way. It’s whipped, so it’s super light and fluffy, like cool buttercream frosting. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it touches your skin. Doesn’t feel greasy. Just disappears.

I started using it on my wrecked hands. Just at night before bed. The first thing I noticed was that it actually soaked in. That blue bottle lotion never did that. This tallow stuff just… went away. My skin drank it. And in the morning, my hands were softer. Not perfect, but better. No tight feeling. I kept using it.

Here’s the thing about commercial moisturizers, I think. They have a million ingredients. Water is always first. Then a bunch of chemicals to make it feel silky, and preservatives so it lasts on a shelf for three years. It’s like giving your skin a glass of water with a bunch of artificial sweeteners. It might feel okay for a second, but it’s not nourishment. This tallow balm is literally just whipped beef tallow from grass-fed cows and some vanilla. That’s it. It’s food for your skin. Apparently, the fat from cows is really close to the oil our own skin makes. So our skin knows what to do with it. It’s not a foreign substance. It’s like… recognizing an old friend. My skin was just so thirsty for something real.

## What This Stuff Actually Does (For Me)

So after a week of just hands, I got brave. My face gets so dry and flaky in winter. Windburn. I looked like a lizard. I’d tried this fancy French moisturizer my sister gave me for my birthday. Felt nice going on. Did nothing. Fifty dollars for nothing. I put a tiny, tiny bit of the tallow balm on my cheeks and forehead one night. I was prepared to wake up a greaseball.

I didn’t.

I woke up and my face was calm. The red, wind-whipped patches on my cheeks were just… quieter. The flakiness was gone. Not covered up. Gone. I was shocked. I’ve been using it as my night cream ever since. In the morning, my skin just feels balanced. Not oily. Not dry. Just normal. My foundation goes on better, which is a weird bonus I didn’t expect.

I also get these rough patches on my elbows. Always have. Like permanent goosebumps. I’ve scrubbed them, slathered them in every lotion under the sun. Nothing changed. I started rubbing a little balm on them after my shower. Just a dab. After maybe four days, I was sitting at my desk at work and I absentmindedly rubbed my elbow. And I stopped. It was smooth. Actually smooth. I almost called my coworker over to feel it, but that would have been too weird. It was just… wild. It fixed something I thought was just part of my body.

The jar is made in France, which feels fancy, but you use so little of it. I’ve had mine since December and I’ve barely made a dent. It’s not cheap, but it lasts forever, so it ends up being cheaper than constantly buying drugstore stuff that doesn’t work.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly, it is. Because it’s so similar to our own skin’s sebum, it absorbs deeply and doesn’t just sit on top clogging pores. It’s like giving your skin the building blocks it actually needs to repair itself. My face has never been happier in winter.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not for me, and I can get clogged pores pretty easy. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t. The key is to use a tiny amount. Like, half the size of a pea for your whole face. It melts right in.

**What does Bourbon Vanilla tallow balm smell like?**
It’s a warm, cozy vanilla. Not like dessert or a candle. It’s deeper. More like the scent of a vanilla pod itself, kind of earthy and sweet but not sugary. It’s really subtle once it’s on your skin. Just a nice, comforting smell.

So yeah. I’m a convert. I’m on my second jar now, because I wanted one for my bedside and one for my bag. I got one for my mom too, for her psoriasis on her elbows. She was skeptical too, but she texted me last week saying it’s the only thing that’s given her relief.

If you’re frustrated with lotions that don’t work, if your skin feels tight and angry no matter what you put on it, this might be worth a shot. It sounds bizarre. Beef tallow skincare. I know. But sometimes the simple, ancient stuff is the answer. All those complicated bottles with twenty-five ingredients didn’t do for me what one jar of whipped tallow did. My skin just… finally shut up and healed. Anyway. My coffee’s cold now. But my hands are soft. That’s all I wanted.
